[[File:Kenny Neal.jpg|thumb|Neal performing at New Orleans [[Jazzfest]] in 2012]]
'''Kenny Neal''' (born October 14, 1957, [[New Orleans, Louisiana|New Orleans]], [[Louisiana]]<ref name="ReferenceA">[{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p476|pure_url=yes}} Allmusic biography data]</ref>), son of [[Raful Neal]], is an [[United States|American]] [[blues]] [[guitar]] player, [[singing|singer]] and band member. Neal comes from a musical family and has often performed with his [[sibling|brothers]] in his [[band (music)|band]].

==Career==
Neal preserves the blues sound of his native south Louisiana, as befits someone who learned from [[Slim Harpo]], [[Buddy Guy]] and his father, the harmonica player, Raful Neal.<ref name="russell">{{cite book
| first= Tony
| last= Russell
| year= 1997
| title= The Blues: From Robert Johnson to Robert Cray
| edition= 
| publisher= Carlton Books Limited 
| location= Dubai
| isbn= 1-85868-255-X
| page= 150}}</ref>

In 1987, Neal cut his debut [[album]] for the [[Florida]] [[record producer]], Bob Greenlee — an updated swamp feast initially marketed on King Snake Records as ''Bio on the Bayou''. [[Alligator Records]] picked it up the following year, retitled it ''Big News from Baton Rouge!!''<ref name="ReferenceA"/> 

In 1991 he also proved to be a talented actor in the [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] production of the [[folk music|folk]] [[Musical theatre|musical]] ''[[Mule Bone]]'' (by [[Langston Hughes]] and [[Zora Neale Hurston]]), singing numbers written by [[Taj Mahal (musician)|Taj Mahal]].<ref name="russell"/>

Neal has played with blues stars including [[Lucky Peterson]] and [[Lazy Lester]], and was at one time a member of The [[Downchild Blues Band]], during a period of relocation to [[Toronto]].<ref>Craig Harris, [{{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p17122|pure_url=yes}} Biography of The Downchild Blues Band]; www.allmusic.com.</ref> 

In September 2006 Neal announced he was taking a year's break from [[sound recording and reproduction|recording]] and performing, due to an undisclosed illness.<ref>[http://www.livingblues.com/showNews.php?ID=42 Living Blues website]</ref> He returned to the public eye at the Monterey Blues Festival in June 2007. His illness was also disclosed as [[Hepatitis C]].  He has children named Kenny, Syreeta, and Micah.<ref>[http://www.montereycountyweekly.com/archives/2007/2007-Jun-21/Article.cover_story_4/1/@@index Monterey County Weekly - accessed January 2008]</ref>

Lately he is touring with ''[[Efes Beverage Group|Efes Pilsen]] Blues Festival''.<ref>[http://blog.efespilsen.com.tr/2010/10/04/efes-pilsen-blues-festival-ile-blues-firtinasi-basladi Efes Pilsen Official Blog - accessed October 2010]</ref>

==Awards==
{{BLP unsourced section|date=December 2012}}
'''Honors'''

* 2011 - Inducted into the Louisiana Music Hall of Fame
* 2005 - Official Statement to Kenny Neal, by the Governor of Louisiana
* 1993 - Washington, D.C., USIA Certificate of Appreciation for representing the U.S. with Kenny Neal's Blues Band for tour in Africa

'''Winner'''

* 2011 - Jus' Blues Music Foundation Contemporary/Traditional Blues Song Of The Year for "Hooked on Your Love"
* 2011 - Critic's Poll Living Blues Award for Best Contemporary Blues Album of the Year
* 2009 - Monterey Bay Blues (M.O.B.B.A.Y.) Artist of the Year Award
* 2009 - BMA ([[Blues Music Award]]) Winner for Song of the Year, "Let Life Flow"
* 2009 - West Coast Blues Hall of Fame Awards for Blues CD of the Year "Let Life Flow" and Blues Band of the Year
* 2009 - Blueswax Album of the Year "Let Life Flow"
* 2008 - Blues Critic Awards Readers Poll, Blues Album of the Year "Let Life Flow" and also Contemporary Blues Artist of the Year
* 2008 - Jus' Blues Awards "Junior Wells Harp Award"
* 2008 - Hometown Video Awards, Entertainment Talk Show
* 2007 - W.A.V.E. Award, Talk Show-Entertainment/Pro
* 2005 - W.C. Handy Blues Awards - Acoustic Blues Album
* 2003 - Slim Harpo Award in Baton Rouge
* 1994 - Theatre World Award "Outstanding New Talent" on Broadway
* 1989 - Big Bill Broonzy Award in Paris
* 1989 - JD Miller Award "Outstanding Performance"

'''Nominated'''

* 2009 - Grammy entries for Grammy Nominations in 4 categories
* 1999 - Grammy Nomination for Tribute to Howlin' Wolf "Best Traditional Blues Album"
